title: 103_hr5098
content: The "Fort Peck Tribes- Montana Compact Act of 1994" approves and ratifies the Fort Peck Indian Tribes-Montana Compact, along with agreements related to water rights. The Fort Peck Indian Tribes may enter into Water Agreements for the delivery, use, or transfer of water rights confirmed in the Compact, not exceeding 50 years, with approval from the Secretary. The Fort Peck Indian Tribes can enter Water Agreements for their confirmed water rights for up to 50 years, with approval from the Secretary within specified timeframes. Within 180 days of submitting the agreement or modification to the Secretary, or 60 days after compliance with relevant laws, a party to a Water Agreement can enforce provisions in accordance with section 1361 of title 28, United States Code. The Department of the Interior must treat information confidentially. The Department of the Interior must treat information related to Water Agreements as privileged, proprietary information of the Tribes, in accordance with section 1361 of title 28, United States Code. The Tribes' financial benefits from Water Agreements are considered privileged information. The Tribes are restricted from entering into agreements allowing tribal water rights to be used outside the Basin. An "Assiniboine and Sioux Tribes Economic Recovery Fund" is established in the US Treasury for economic development starting in fiscal year 1996. An "Assiniboine and Sioux Tribes Economic Recovery Fund" is established in the US Treasury for economic development, with 10% of receipts from integrated programs of the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin Project deposited annually, capped at $50,000,000. The "Assiniboine and Sioux Tribes Economic Recovery Fund" is established in the US Treasury for economic development, with a cap of $50,000,000. The interest accrued on deposits to the fund is deposited in a separate account and available for tribal economic development. The "Assiniboine and Sioux Tribes Economic Recovery Fund" in the US Treasury is available for tribal economic development and land acquisition within the Reservation, starting from fiscal year 1999. Payments are made for economic development and land acquisition, subject to Secretary approval. The fund's principal cannot be used for payments. Amounts deposited in the fund are nonreimbursable. The "Assiniboine and Sioux Tribes Economic Recovery Fund" allows for tribal economic development and land acquisition within the Reservation, starting from fiscal year 1999. Payments for land acquisition require Secretary approval and are nonreimbursable. No reduction in Federal services or programs for the Tribes or their members is allowed due to payments under this Act. Payments are not subject to Federal or State income tax and do not affect power rates in the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin. The "Assiniboine and Sioux Tribes Economic Recovery Fund" allows for tribal economic development and land acquisition within the Reservation, starting from fiscal year 1999. Payments under this Act are not subject to Federal or State income tax and do not affect power rates in the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin. No part of the funds shall be distributed on a per capita basis to any member of the Tribes. In return for the United States' actions required by this Act, the Tribes waive and release any existing claims against the United States. The Tribes waive and release any existing claims against the United States in return for the performance of all actions required by the Act, including funding for the Fund. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The Fort Peck Indian Tribes-Montana Compact refers to the water rights agreement ratified in 1985. The Reservation is defined as the Fort Peck Indian Reservation. The Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The agreement of December 28, 1886, and December 31, 1886, confirmed by the Act approved May 1, 1888, defines terms such as "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior, "Tribes" as the Assiniboine and Sioux Tribes of the Fort Peck Indian Reservation, "tribal water right" as defined in the Fort Peck-Montana Compact, and "Fund" as the Assiniboine and Sioux Tribes Economic Recovery Fund.
